adjectives.description: upstream (comparative farther or further upstream, superlative farthest or furthest upstream)

entries.meaning: In a direction against the flow of a current or stream of fluid (typically water); upriver.

definitionGroups.group: (metaphoric) Occurring earlier than something else; (also, usually, especially) being an influence on something else; causing a consequence for something else.

entries.meaning: (oil industry) Involving exploration and pre-production rather than refining and selling.
(computer networking) In the direction from the client to the server.
(open-source software) Maintained, owned, or associated with the original developers of the given software; in contrast to a modified version downstream.
examples: You can also check the upstream and/or Debian bug trackers for open and closed bugs and the upstream revision history or newer release(s).

entries.meaning: (biology) Towards the leading end (5′ end) of a DNA molecule.

adverbs.description: upstream (comparative more upstream, superlative most upstream)

entries.meaning: Part of the river towards the upstream direction.
examples: The total depth of water at the upstream was measured by using a pointer attached to a carriage sitting on the water table walls.

entries.meaning: (open-source software) The original developers or maintainers of software.

verbs.description: upstream (third-person singular simple present upstreams, present participle upstreaming, simple past and past participle upstreamed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, open-source software) To have (a software library, patch, etc.) accepted by the original developers of the related software, so that they maintain and distribute it.
examples: I'd be more than happy to upstream your patch.
